Line 17: Line 17:      
== Etymology ==
 
== Etymology ==
−
In origins, '''love''' is an [[Indo-Iranian]] word set to characterize a state, relationship, or situation which is ''pleasing'' to the ''desires''.
+
In origins, approximately, the word ''love'' is a grammatical evolution of a 12th century [[Indo-Iranian]] word set to characterize a state, relationship, or situation which is: <div style="font-size:150%">{{cquote|pleasing to the desires}}</div>
−
+
According to the [[Oxford English Dictionary]], the English word "love" is derived more immediately from [[Old English]] lufu, luvu, or lubu, which derived from luba of [[Old High German]]. The luba of Old High German derived from leubh, lubet, and libet of [[Sanskrit]] and Old Aryan, meaning “pleasing.”
−
According to the [[Oxford English Dictionary]], the English word "love" is derived more immediately from [[Old English]] lufu, luvu, or lubu, which derived from luba of [[Old High German]]. The luba of Old High German derived from leubh, lubet, and libet of [[Sanskrit]] and [[Old Aryan]], meaning “pleasing.”
       
According to the [[Online Etymology Dictionary]], the following derivations exist: O.E. lufu "love, affection, friendliness," from P.Gmc. *lubo (cf. O.Fris. liaf, Ger. lieb, Goth. liufs "dear, beloved;" not found elsewhere as a noun, except O.H.G. luba, Ger. Liebe), from PIE *leubh- "to care, desire, love" (cf. L. lubet, later libet "pleases;" Skt. lubhyati "desires;" O.C.S. l'ubu "dear, beloved;" Lith. liaupse "song of praise"). Meaning "a beloved person" is from c.1225.
 
According to the [[Online Etymology Dictionary]], the following derivations exist: O.E. lufu "love, affection, friendliness," from P.Gmc. *lubo (cf. O.Fris. liaf, Ger. lieb, Goth. liufs "dear, beloved;" not found elsewhere as a noun, except O.H.G. luba, Ger. Liebe), from PIE *leubh- "to care, desire, love" (cf. L. lubet, later libet "pleases;" Skt. lubhyati "desires;" O.C.S. l'ubu "dear, beloved;" Lith. liaupse "song of praise"). Meaning "a beloved person" is from c.1225.
